customer_name: MELODI L. CONNOR CHRISTOPHER J. CONNOR

citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
Regularly scheduled visits to the facility by the Attending Veterinarian are not occurring. The facility’s written program of
veterinary care indicates that regularly scheduled visits to the premises by the veterinarian are to occur annually, however
the Attending Veterinarian has not been to the facility in over two years.
Not following the instructions of the attending veterinarian and infrequent routine facility visits risks the health and well-
being of the animals. Correct by ensuring that the Program of Veterinary Care is followed and that regular visits to the
premises by the Attending Veterinarian are occurring at the frequency defined in the program, but not less than annually.

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
There is an accumulation of soiled bedding, food waste, and debris on the floor of the grivet enclosure. Additionally, the
enclosure walls have a build up of hard, dried debris. Primary enclosures with excessive waste and debris can increase
the prevalence of insects, pests, and disease hazards. Correct by 26 April 2024 by cleaning all primary enclosures with
sufficient frequency to ensure the animals have the freedom to avoid contact with excreta and to reduce disease hazards,
insects, pests, and odors.

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
The facility is sanitizing the non-human primate enclosures once a month as opposed to once every two weeks. An
insufficient frequency of primary enclosure sanitation can lead to increased disease risks to the animals and pest control
issues. Correct by 3 May 2024 by sanitizing all primary enclosures, at least once every 2 weeks or as often as necessary
to prevent an excessive accumulation of dirt, debris, waste, food waste, excreta, or disease hazards. Ensure sanitization
is being performed by one of the methods detailed in 3,84(b)(3).

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
The facility does not have an effective program in place to control for insect pests. There are large numbers of fruit flies
around the enclosures and on the facility walls. The facility has implemented numerous control strategies but so far have
been unsuccessful in controlling the populations. Excessive pests and insects can lead to potential contamination of food
and affect the well-being of the animals. Correct by 17 May 2024 by establishing and maintaining an effective program to
control insects and external parasites to promote the health and well-being of the animals and reduce contamination by
pests in animal areas.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
n

narrative:
2.40(a)(1)  Repeat
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
Regularly scheduled visits to the facility by the Attending Veterinarian are not occurring. The facility’s written program of 
veterinary care indicates that regularly scheduled visits to the premises by the veterinarian are to occur annually, however 
the Attending Veterinarian has not been to the facility in over two years. 
 
Not following the instructions of the attending veterinarian and infrequent routine facility visits risks the health and well-
being of the animals. Correct by ensuring that the Program of Veterinary Care is followed and that regular visits to the 
premises by the Attending Veterinarian are occurring at the frequency defined in the program, but not less than annually. 
3.84(a) 
   
Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control. 
There is an accumulation of soiled bedding, food waste, and debris on the floor of the grivet enclosure. Additionally, the 
enclosure walls have a build up of hard, dried debris. Primary enclosures with excessive waste and debris can increase 
the prevalence of insects, pests, and disease hazards. Correct by 26 April 2024 by cleaning all primary enclosures with 
sufficient frequency to ensure the animals have the freedom to avoid contact with excreta and to reduce disease hazards, 
insects, pests, and odors. 
3.84(b)(2) 
   
Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control. 
The facility is sanitizing the non-human primate enclosures once a month as opposed to once every two weeks. An 
insufficient frequency of primary enclosure sanitation can lead to increased disease risks to the animals and pest control 
issues. Correct by 3 May 2024 by sanitizing all primary enclosures, at least once every 2 weeks or as often as necessary 
to prevent an excessive accumulation of dirt, debris, waste, food waste, excreta, or disease hazards. Ensure sanitization 
is being performed by one of the methods detailed in 3,84(b)(3). 
3.84(d) 
   
Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.

The facility does not have an effective program in place to control for insect pests. There are large numbers of fruit flies 
around the enclosures and on the facility walls. The facility has implemented numerous control strategies but so far have 
been unsuccessful in controlling the populations. Excessive pests and insects can lead to potential contamination of food 
and affect the well-being of the animals. Correct by 17 May 2024 by establishing and maintaining an effective program to 
control insects and external parasites to promote the health and well-being of the animals and reduce contamination by 
pests in animal areas. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives. 
 
 n
